summary: The appellant, Philip Dim, was convicted of murdering his wife by attacking her with a pickaxe-head in the early hours of the morning. He claimed a 'black-out' due to mental illness, asserting he had no memory of the event. The trial judge rejected this defence, finding no supporting medical or testimonial evidence. On appeal, it was argued that the prosecution failed to prove intent, that the judge misdirected himself on the insanity defence, and that the Crown should have led medical evidence on sanity. The West African Court of Appeal dismissed the appeal, holding that intent to murder could be inferred from the violent act, that the burden of proving insanity lies with the defence under Section 27 of the Criminal Code, and that the trial judge was correct in requiring credible evidence to support the 'black-out' claim, which was absent.
